questions.text: 1. A patient underwent surgery for a duodenal ulcer. During the procedure, the surgeon accidentally injured a structure posterior to the epiploic foramen, and the patient started bleeding copiously into the peritoneal cavity. Which is the most likely structure injured by the surgeon?
questions.solution:
Inferior vena cava (IVC) is the most likely structure injured by the surgeon as it is present in the posterior part of the epiploic foramen.

The epiploic foramen (foramen of Winslow or aditus to the lesser sac) is a short vertical slit situated immediately posterior to the right free margin of the lesser omentum. It is the entrance to the lesser sac from the greater sac.





Clinical note: Pringle maneuver (as shown below) is a technique where the free margin of the lesser omentum is compressed to obtain rapid control of the hepatic artery and portal vein in liver trauma and surgery.



Pearl PM1129: Relations of epiploic foramen and lesser sac

  • Hepatoduodenal ligament containing hepatic artery, portal vein, and common bile duct

Posterior
  • Inferior vena cava
  • Right suprarenal gland
  • Body of T12 vertebra

  • Caudate process of the liver

Inferior
  • 1st part of duodenum

questions.text: 2. A patient presented with the following findings in the left lower limb. Identify the true statement regarding the condition.

choices.text: Sclerotherapy is the treatment of choice for this stage

questions.solution:
The image above shows dilated, tortuous veins of the lower limb and suggests stage C2 as per the CEAP classification. The patient will develop eczema/ pigmentation. 

Varicose veins are characterised by the tortuous dilatation of subcutaneous veins resulting from venous insufficiency. Patients have heaviness, burning, and aching over the affected area or whole limb, which increases throughout the day or on prolonged standing. If the corrective measures are not taken, the varicose veins can progress to develop pigmentation, eczema and even venous ulcers. 

Risk factors (Option D):

* Females>males

* Increasing age

* Increasing body mass and height

* Pregnancy

* Family history

* Occupations involving prolonged periods of standing

Investigations include: 

* Clinical examination

* Venous duplex ultrasound

* Site of reflux

* Size of vein

* Location of perforators

* Presence of obstruction in the deep venous system

* Indication of pelvic source of reflux or obstruction

* MR venography

* Invasive procedures such as contrast venography or intravenous ultrasound.

Management can be done through various methods, and it depends on the surgeon. Many times, the procedures are grouped. (Option B)

* Endovascular procedures

* Endovascular laser ablation

* Radiofrequency ablation

* Ultrasound-guided foam sclerotherapy

* Catheter-directed sclerotherapy and mechanochemical ablation

* Endovenous glue

* Open surgeries

* Saphenofemoral ligation and great saphenous vein stripping

* Saphenopopliteal junction ligation and small saphenous vein stripping

* Non-surgical procedures like Compression stockings

Image A shows tortuous dilated veins (C2), Image B is atrophie blanche (C4b), and Image C shows fan-shaped telangiectasia (C4c).



The images below show C5 and C6 - healed and active venous ulcers, respectively.

questions.text: 3. An elderly male presented with epigastric pain, anorexia, weight loss and jaundice since 2 years. He had scratch marks over the body. On examination, the gall bladder was palpable, smooth and non-tender. Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly male presenting with epigastric pain, anorexia, weight loss and jaundice for 2 years with a palpable, smooth and non-tender gall bladder suggests the most probable diagnosis to be carcinoma of the head of the pancreas.

Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas presents with jaundice that occurs secondary to obstruction of the distal bile duct. It can also be associated with nausea, epigastric discomfort, weight loss, pruritus, dark urine and pale stools with steatorrhoea. In the absence of jaundice, symptoms are often non-specific, such as vague discomfort, anorexia and weight loss.

On examination, there may be evidence of a palpable liver and a palpable gallbladder. According to Courvoisier's Law, in a patient with jaundice, with a palpable, enlarged, non-tender gallbladder, the cause is unlikely to be due to gallstones and is more likely to be due to a periampullary malignancy. This is because the common bile duct obstruction by gallstones would lead to chronic inflammation, which causes the gallbladder to shrink and become fibrotic. The gallbladder is enlarged in conditions causing a slow occlusion, as in tumours surrounding the distal common bile duct, which implicates possible cancer of the head of the pancreas.

With widespread disease, a left supraclavicular node (Virchow node) and a periumbilical lymph node (Sister Mary Joseph node) may be palpable. In cases of peritoneal dissemination, perirectal tumour involvement may be palpable through digital rectal examination, known as the Blumer shelf.

Other options:

Option A: Choledocholithiasis is usually asymptomatic. Symptomatic patients with cholangitis have bouts of pain, jaundice and fever, known as Charcot’s triad. 

Option C: Patients with carcinoma of the gall bladder may be asymptomatic. If symptoms are present, they are usually indistinguishable from those of benign gallbladder disease, such as biliary colic or cholecystitis, particularly in older patients. Jaundice, palpable mass and anorexia are late features.

Option D: Hepatocellular carcinoma is most commonly seen in men 50 to 60 years of age who complain of right upper quadrant abdominal pain, weight loss and have a palpable mass. Presentation at an advanced stage is often with vague right upper quadrant abdominal pain that sometimes radiates to the right shoulder. Other nonspecific symptoms that can be seen are anorexia, nausea, lethargy, and weight loss.

questions.text: 5. Identify the type of suture material given in the image.
questions.solution:
Polydioxanone is a monofilament suture.

Polydioxanone is a slowly absorbing monofilament suture. Since they are monofilament sutures, they can resist infection better than braided multifilament sutures. It is used in abdominal wall closure.



An ideal suture material for abdominal wall closure should:

* Resist infection

* Provide adequate tensile strength to prevent abdominal wall disruption

* Reduce tissue damage

* Be an absorbable material

questions.text: 6. A malignant neck swelling was surgically removed from a patient, shown in the image below. What will the patient likely present with 2-3 days after the procedure?
questions.solution:
The given image suggests total thyroidectomy, and the patient is likely to present with carpopedal spasm 2-3 days after the procedure.

Thyroid surgery, particularly total thyroidectomy with a concomitant central neck dissection, is the most common cause of hypoparathyroidism. There is transient hypocalcemia due to ischemia of the parathyroid glands, but permanent hypoparathyroidism is rare. Hypoparathyroidism can also occur after parathyroid surgery.

Hypoparathyroidism results in hypocalcemia. Acute hypocalcemia leads to decreased ionised calcium and increased neuromuscular excitability. Patients initially experience numbness in the circumoral and fingertip areas along with a tingling sensation. 

Other symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia:

* Chvostek sign: contraction of facial muscles that is elicited by tapping on the facial nerve anterior to the ear

* Trousseau's sign: carpopedal spasm that is elicited by occluding blood flow to the forearm with a blood pressure cuff for 2–3 minutes

* Mental symptoms like anxiety, confusion, and depression

* Laryngeal stridor

* Convulsions

Intravenous calcium infusion is rarely required and most patients with post-operative hypocalcemia can be treated with oral calcium and vitamin D supplements. 

Other options:

Option A: Deviation of the angle of the mouth is seen in injury of the marginal mandibular nerve and facial nerve palsy. 

Option B: Hoarseness of voice occurs in laryngeal disorders like tumours and recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy.

Option D: Migratory thrombophlebitis occurs in vascular diseases such as Buerger's disease.

questions.text: 7. A 25-year-old male presented to the emergency with a stab injury on the right iliac region. A few hours later, he developed hypotension, abdominal tenderness and peritonitis. Which is the next best management?
questions.solution:
The next best management in the given scenario of a stab injury to the abdomen is emergency laparotomy.

Emergency laparotomy is performed to explore and repair abdominal injuries in case of: 

* Hemodynamic instability

* Peritonitis

* Evisceration

Other options:

Option D: Diagnostic peritoneal lavage is used to assess the presence of blood or contaminants in the abdomen. It is rarely used nowadays.

questions.text: 8. An 8-year-old child presents with progressive phimosis and a white sclerotic lesion seen on the penis. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with progressive phimosis and the image showing a white sclerotic lesion on the penis, is suggestive of  Balanitis Xerotica Obliterans.

Balanitis Xerotica Obliterans is a chronic, preputial inflammation that may also affect the distal urethra. It is rarely seen before 5 years of age and can occur due to autoimmunity. Boys present with progressive phimosis and white, hard preputial skin, dysuria and ballooning on micturition. It is treated by circumcision, but some boys respond to topical corticosteroids. Follow-up is required to prevent meatal stenosis. 

Other options:

Option A: Meatal stenosis occurs as a complication of Balanitis Xerotica Obliterans.

Option B: Hypospadiasis is a congenital malformation in which the urethral opening lies on the ventral aspect of the penis, anywhere from the proximal glans to the perineum in association with a ventral curvature (called a chordee) and a ventrally deficient foreskin leading to a dorsal ‘hooded’ prepuce. 

The image below shows penoscrotal hypospadias.



Option C: Paraphimosis is a condition where the prepuce retracts back over the glans and cannot be brought forward again. The glans swells and becomes painful. The image below shows paraphimosis.

questions.text: 9. The following image depicting bile duct injury shows which type of Strasberg classification?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a bile leak from the cystic duct stump and a minor biliary radicle in the gallbladder fossa. According to Strasberg’s classification, the image given belongs to type A bile duct injury.

Biliary injury may occur post-laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The most common site of bile leak following cholecystectomy is the cystic duct.

The Strasberg classification of bile duct injury is a widely used system to anatomically define these injuries by location:

* Type A: Bile leak from the cystic duct stump or a minor biliary radicle in the gallbladder fossa

* Type B: Occluded right posterior sectoral duct

* Type C: Bile leak from the divided right posterior sectoral duct

* Type D: Bile leak from the main bile duct without major tissue loss

* Type E: Injury to the main hepatic duct; classified according to the level of injury

* E1: Transected main bile duct with a stricture more than 2cm from the hilus

* E2: Transected main bile duct with a stricture less than 2cm from the hilus

* E3: Stricture of the hilus with right and left ducts in communication

* E4: Stricture of the hilus with separation of right and left hepatic ducts

* E5: Stricture of the right aberrant sectoral duct and the main bile duct

MRCP is the gold standard for evaluating the biliary tree's morphology completely. MRCP with magnetic resonance angiography is more useful in cases of associated vascular injury. An HIDA scan can confirm the presence of a bile leak or biliary obstruction. 

For an unstable patient, temporary external biliary drainage is achieved by passing a catheter percutaneously into an intrahepatic duct. When the condition improves, definitive surgery can be undertaken. The main principle of surgery is to maintain the duct length and the restoration of biliary drainage.

questions.text: 10. What is the diagnosis in the given image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a hand with an edematous and putrefied appearance of the fingers and palm, with a poor line of demarcation, suggestive of Wet Gangrene.

Wet gangrene results from the blockage of both arterial and venous blood supply, along with a superadded infection and tissue putrefaction.

Dry gangrene Wet gangrene 
Clear line of demarcation  Vague line of demarcation 
Dry, shriveled, mummified appearance  Edematous putrefied discoloured appearance 
Slow, gradual loss of blood supply Sudden loss of blood supply
Separation by aseptic ulceration  Separation by septic ulceration 
Treatment - limited amputation  Treatment - aggressive amputation 
Causes - Thromboangiitis obliterans (TAO), atherosclerosis, etc Causes - emboli, trauma, etc


The following image shows dry gangrene of the 4th right toe:



Other options:

Option C: Tenosynovitis, which is an inflammation of the tendon sheaths of infectious/non-infectious origin, is characterized by Kanavel signs, which include a swollen finger held in flexion, severe pain on passive extension, tenderness along the tendon sheath, with the greatest tenderness over the part of the ulnar bursa located between the transverse palmar creases.



Option D: Raynaud's phenomenon occurs due to peripheral vasospasm, resulting in pallor, cyanosis, followed by reactive hyperemia in the extremities.

questions.text: 11. A 30 year old female underwent the procedure shown in the image following a burn injury. Which statement is true regarding this procedure?

choices.text: Done to save the artery in the arm

questions.solution:
The given image shows escharotomy, which is done in circumferential burns.

Emergency surgery is required for circumferential full-thickness burns to the limbs and torso. The burn has a tourniquet-like effect, which can lead to a compromise in respiration (torso) and peripheral circulation (limbs). The tourniquet effect of this injury is treated by incising the whole length of full-thickness burns.

For the chest, two longitudinal and two horizontal incisions are made. There should be evidence of immediate improvement of respiration and, if intubated, the ventilation pressures after performing escharotomy. For the limbs, the escharotomy incision is performed in the midaxial line to avoid major nerves. An escharotomy can cause significant blood loss, and hence, the use of cutting diathermy and appropriate dressings must be considered along with the availability of blood for transfusion.

Key features of escharotomy placement:

* Chest: Down the chest lateral to the nipples, across the chest below the clavicle and across the chest at the level of the xiphisternum

* Upper limb: Mid-axial, anterior to the elbow, medially to avoid the ulnar nerve

* Hand: Midline in the digits. Release muscle compartments if tight, and this is best done in theatre. 

* Lower limb: Mid-axial. Posterior to the ankle, medially to avoid the saphenous vein.

The image below shows escharotomy.

questions.text: 12. Identify the type of anal fistula seen in the image.
questions.solution:
In the given image, the fistula traverses the internal sphincter and tracks down the space between the internal and external anal sphincters. Hence, it is an inter-sphincteric type of anal fistula. 

A fistula-in-ano is a chronic abnormal communication extending from the anorectal lumen (the internal opening) to an external opening on the skin of the perineum or buttock (or rarely, in women, to the vagina). The majority are idiopathic or cryptoglandular and are lined by granulation tissue. Patients usually complain of intermittent purulent discharge and discomfort.

As per the American Gastroenterology Association Classification, anal fistulas can also be classified into simple or complex:

* Simple fistulas are low (superficial or low inter- or low trans-sphincteric tract) and have a single external opening

* Complex fistulas are high (high inter- or trans-sphincteric tract). They have an extra- or suprasphincteric tract with the presence of an abscess or collection. They include ano-vaginal fistula and anal stricture.

questions.text: 13. A 42-year-old woman had a non-specific right upper quadrant pain. The gross section of the excised tumor is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history of non-specific right upper quadrant pain, with the given gross specimen showing a well-circumscribed lesion with a central stellate scar, is suggestive of focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH).

FNH is the second most common benign tumor of the liver after hemangioma. It is commonly seen in young women. It is believed to be a hyperplastic response to an anomalous artery. Patients are mostly asymptomatic, and FNH is often an incidental finding. If symptoms are noted, vague abdominal pain is the most common symptom.

On histological examination, cords of hepatocytes are seen with atypical biliary epithelium scattered throughout. 

Contrast-enhanced CT is diagnostic for focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH). It appears as a well-circumscribed lesion with a central stellate scar containing a large artery branching out in a spoke-wheel pattern. It shows intense homogeneous enhancement in the arterial phase, and it is isodense as compared to the background liver in the venous phase.

The contrast-enhanced CT image of focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) is shown below.



Due to the presence of Kupffer cells, FNH appears as a hotspot on a Tc 99m sulfur colloid scan.

These tumors do not have the risk of malignant transformation; therefore, asymptomatic patients do not require treatment. Careful observation of symptomatic FNH with serial imaging is reasonable, as symptoms may resolve in a significant number of cases. Patients with persistent symptomatic FNH or an enlarging mass should be considered for resection.

Another tumor that can show a central stellate scar is renal oncocytoma.

Other options:

Option A: Metastatic tumor is the most common tumor of the liver. It typically presents as multiple nodular masses leading to hepatomegaly, and these nodules may replace large areas of liver parenchyma. Occasionally, metastatic lesions can appear as a solitary nodule.

Option C: Hepatic adenoma is a well-defined, discrete liver mass that may sometimes be multiple. It is often associated with hemorrhage and carries a risk of rupture, which can lead to massive abdominal bleeding.

Option D: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the most common primary malignant tumor of the liver. It may present as a single large mass or diffusely infiltrate the entire liver. The lipid-rich clear cell variant of HCC shows abundant fat and glycogen in tumor cells. The external surface of the tumor is usually nodular or congested with a tan appearance, while the cut surface is solid and variegated, with areas of cystic change.

Pearl PM1924: Liver tumors - commons

* Most common tumor overall: Metastatic tumor

* Most common primary benign tumor: Cavernous hemangioma

* Most common primary malignant tumor: Hepatocellular carcinoma

* Most common primary malignant liver tumor of early childhood: Hepatoblastoma

* Most common tumor associated with arsenic / vinyl chloride: Angiosarcoma

* Most common tumor associated with oral contraceptive / anabolic steroid: Hepatic adenoma

* Most common tumor rupture spontaneously causing hemoperitoneum: Hepatic adenoma

questions.text: 14. A 45-year-old male presented with difficulty in swallowing and weight loss. The barium swallow gives the following finding along with bronchectatic changes on chest X ray. What is the investigation of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the barium swallow showing a bird beak appearance, is suggestive of achalasia cardia. Manometry is the investigation of choice.

Pearl PM1528: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

* Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.

* Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

* Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)

* Regurgitation

* Chest pain

* Weight loss

* Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy



Pearl PM2445: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance



Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.



Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.



Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.



Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.



Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.



Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.





Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: 15. A patient with hypertensive episodes, with an MRI abdomen showing a suprarenal mass, is planned for surgery. 24-hour urine shows metanephrine levels to be elevated. What drug will be given preoperatively and also intraoperatively?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests the diagnosis to be Pheochromocytoma. The drug that will be given preoperatively and also intraoperatively is Nicardipine.

The medical management of pheochromocytomas requires blood pressure control and volume repletion. Nicardipine is a calcium channel blocker that is commonly used preoperatively. It inhibits norepinephrine-mediated calcium transport into vascular smooth muscle. Nicardipine also helps to control blood pressure intraoperatively. Calcium channel blockers are indicated in patients who are not able to tolerate alpha blockade because of profound orthostasis or for those patients who need additional blood pressure control. It is as effective as alpha and beta blockers, both preoperatively and intraoperatively. 

Preoperatively, blood pressure control is primarily with alpha blockers. Irreversible, long-acting α-blockers such as phenoxybenzamine are started 1 to 3 weeks before surgery. Selective alpha-blockers such as prazosin, doxazosin, and terazosin can also be used. Beta-blockers such as propranolol can be added preoperatively in patients who have persistent tachycardia and arrhythmias. Beta-blockers should be given after adequate alpha-blockade and hydration to avoid the effects of unopposed alpha stimulation, such as hypertensive crisis and congestive heart failure.

Nicardipine, Nitroprusside, Nitroglycerin, and Phentolamine are used for intraoperative control of blood pressure. Esmolol can be administered to control heart rate.

Other options:

Option B: Esmolol is a short-acting beta-blocker that can be used to manage intraoperative arrhythmias.

Option C: Clonidine is an alpha-agonist that suppresses neurogenically mediated catecholamine excess but not secretion from pheochromocytomas.

Option D: Phenoxybenzamine is a long-acting α-blocker that is given preoperatively, usually 1 to 3 weeks before surgery.

Pearl PM1140: Clinical features of Pheochromocytoma (By frequency of occurrence)

* Classical triad of symptoms:

* Headaches – most common symptom

* Profuse sweating

* Palpitations and tachycardia

* Hypertension (sustained or intermittent) – most common sign

* Anxiety, panic attacks

* Hyperglycemia

* Hypercalcemia

* Pallor - due to alpha-1 mediated vasoconstriction

* Polyuria and polydipsia 

* Orthostatic hypotension

* Dilated cardiomyopathy

* Erythrocytosis, high hematocrit (hemoconcentration)

* Constipation

* Abdominal pain

* Weakness

* Weight loss

* Nausea

Pearl PM0788: Pheochromocytoma

Features:

* When pheochromocytoma is associated with the MEN syndrome it is rarely malignant.

* Phaeochromocytomas are greyish-pink on the cut surface and are usually highly vascularised.

* Zellbalen cells and nuclei with salt and pepper chromatin are seen.

Factors indicating more chances of malignancy:

* An increased PASS (phaeochromocytoma of the adrenal gland scale score)

* High number of Ki-67-positive cells

* Vascular invasion or a breached capsule

Diagnosis:

* Measurement of the plasma metanephrines is the most sensitive screening test.

* MRI is the IOC.

* Biopsy and CT Contrast scans are contraindicated in order to avoid a hypertensive crisis.

Treatment:

* Adrenalectomy is preferred TOC.

* Size<5 cm -  Laparoscopic adrenalectomy

* Preop Alpha blockers should be given

questions.text: 16. A patient presented with odynophagia and cervical lymphadenitis. On examination, an ulcerated growth was present on the base of the tongue, which was found to be squamous cell carcinoma. What is the most common organism associated?
questions.solution:
HPV is the most common organism associated with squamous cell carcinoma.

In the oropharynx, most of the squamous cell carcinomas (SCC), particularly those involving the tonsils, the base of the tongue, and the pharynx, occur due to oncogenic variants of HPV.

Early detection of HPV-associated head and neck SCC can be delayed because the anatomic sites of origin (tonsillar crypts, base of tongue, and oropharynx) are not readily accessible for cytologic screening (unlike the cervix) for premalignant lesions. The presenting features of oropharyngeal SCC include multiple large cystic cervical lymph nodes with a small primary lesion.

Early-stage tumours may be cured by transoral laser surgery, transoral robotic surgery or radiotherapy. Intermediate- or late-stage disease is usually managed with concurrent chemoradiotherapy or with open surgery and reconstruction using myocutaneous pedicles or free flaps. Larger lesions with recurrences require open surgery and reconstruction. Neck dissection is required in most cases where surgery is the primary treatment modality and is also required for patients who have only partially responded following chemoradiotherapy.

Pearl PM0271: Risk Factors for Squamous Cell Carcinoma

Risk factors for squamous cell carcinoma

* UV exposure

* Male sex- due to more sun exposure

* Environmental factors-

* Psoralen and UVA (PUVA)

* Physical agents such as ionizing radiation

* Chemical agents such as arsenics

* HPV-16 & 18

* Immunosuppression 

* Smoking

* Chronic nonhealing wounds, burn scars, and chronic dermatosis

* Hereditary conditions such as xeroderma pigmentosum, epidermolysis bullosa, and oculo-cutaneous albinism

* Premalignant conditions like actinic keratosis, Bowen’s disease, erythroplasia of Queyrat

questions.text: 17. A 25-year-old following a RTA with head injury was brought to the ER, and a CT scan showed normal findings, but the patient died within 3 hours. Autopsy showed petechial hemorrhages in the corpus callosum, focal lesions in the brain stem, and retraction ball appearance in the internal capsule. What is the cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a normal CT and the given autopsy findings are probably due to a diffuse axonal injury.

A diffuse axonal injury is a form of primary brain injury seen in high-energy accidents. It is caused by damage to axons throughout the brain due to rotational acceleration and then deceleration. Axons may be completely disrupted and then retract, forming axon balls.

Small hemorrhages can be seen in more severe cases, especially on MRI (investigation of choice). Hemorrhage is classically seen in the corpus callosum and the dorsolateral midbrain. The prognosis is very poor.

MRI showing multiple hypointense punctate foci within the subcortical and deep white matter within the corpus callosum is characteristic of diffuse axonal injury.



Pearl PM2128: Diffuse Axonal Injury

The mechanism of diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is primarily a non-impact rotational acceleration-deceleration injury. This leads to the deformation of the axons by stretching them.

Pathology of DAI:

* Changes in permeability of the axolemma

* Axonal swelling

* Intracellular calcium accumulation

* Proteolysis

* The collapse of the cytoskeleton

* 'Retraction balls or globes' - bulbous and clubbed axons. Seen earliest at 12-18 hours. The number of retraction balls begins to decrease after 2-3 weeks after injury and a cluster of microglial cells appears followed by astrocytosis and demyelination.

* Immuno-histochemistry shows beta-amyloid precursor protein - the most reliable indicator of axon damage. Seen earliest at 2-3 hours.

questions.text: 18. A patient presented with lump on right breast. Biopsy was done, which confirms breast cancer. Identify the stage of breast cancer.
questions.solution:
The given image shows erythema, edema, and dimpling (peau d'orange appearance) on the right breast, suggestive of the T4d stage of breast cancer.

T4d suggests inflammatory breast carcinoma with peau d’orange appearance and redness involving >1/3rd of the surface of the breast, with or without a breast lump. Peau d’orange refers to the orange peel appearance of the skin of the breast and is a sign of locally advanced disease.

Prefixes for TNM staging:

* c: clinical staging (e.g. cT1b)

* p: pathological (histological) staging

* y: stage following systemic or radiation therapy (either prior to surgery or as a primary treatment)

* r: staging at the time of retreatment or recurrence for disease progression

Suffix for TNM staging:

* m: multiple primary tumours of the same histology in the same organ, e.g. T2(m) or T2(5), the latter meaning that there are five primary tumours
